At IBM I am encouraged to be myself and not being afraid or ashamed of who I am. There is an environment of respect and inclusion where the most important thing is my professional performance, my knowledge and my skills. Not my sexual orientation. Work at home options and job flexibility

- Most of my HR partners have been amazing. (Unfortunately they just announced only upline managers will have an assigned HR contact.  That doesn't have a big impact on me, but will be difficult for new managers or new IBMers).

- I've been able to find good talent for my teams internally in IBM.  I'd say that about 1/3 to 1/2 of the employees on each team I've been in have been extremely dedicated to their work and their customers. 

- The sales org seems to be addressing some of the complacency in their ranks, and I've had very positive experiences with most of the newer sellers they have hired.  It seems there is more pressure now for sellers to take ownership of their accounts *after* (and not just until) their commission comes in.

- It's pretty easy to move internally if you have a good reputation or good performance ratings.  You may encounter resistance from your management, but they're not allowed to block your movement indefinitely.

The schedule is also flexible, if you need to work from another city or work from home to receive a delivery, it usually isn't a problem. Likewise, there are no set number of sick days: if you are sick, you don't come in. This also leads to you tending to work while you are out sick or on vacation (just a quick email check...), which skews your work/life balance a bit.

As a consultant, overall view of company is largely, if not wholly dependent on the client engagement that consultant is staffed on and practice area. I have had a mix of successful, balanced projects as well as challenging. Being out at work as lesbian enabled me to experience helping launch an internal startup -- a business development team dedicated to the LGBT+ B2B market. My management also supported my 6-month assignment in India with my wife, accompanying me, even though homosexual activity is illegal in India; it said that it couldn't get me out of jail if I were jailed due to the country's laws, but that Pat & I could be fully out as a couple within IBM's four walls; we were and local management and colleagues all were lovely to and inclusive of us. My U.S. management also sponsored my Master's at Columbia while I worked full-time. All this while being able to mentor and be mentored by amazing LGBT+ colleagues and allies!

Product cycle is slow and very process oriented. Things don't get done as simple and as fast as they should. Maybe folks there are pretty set in their own ways. Not the most innovative crowd. Don't be stuck in a group that is not performing. Bottom line counts a lot.

In today's hectic business world, people try cramming as much into the work days as possible. When employees are trying to finish up all the tasks on their to-do lists, 40-hour workweeks can easily morph into 45 or 50--and work can begin to impinge on their leisure time. To ease the stress of not having enough free time, some employees look to job sharing-- the process of splitting one full-time job between two people--in order to take back control of their lives and spend it the way they want.

IBM is very self-centered.  It places NO VALUE on its USA workforce.  We are viewed as an  bottom-line expense that needs to be jettisoned as soon as possible.  There is a corporate productivity program referred to as LEAN, but internally we all know it stands for Lay off Every American Now.   And basically that is what they are doing.  Their goal is to move 80% of the existing US workforce to Brazil, India or some other low wage country.  So far in the first quarter of 2009 they have already dumped 20,000 US employees.  Their complete destruction of hundreds of thousands of American lives quite obviously has no bearing on the conscious of the leadership of this company.  They will continue to cut a swath of destruction though their US workforce until "Big Blue" is transformed into a "Big Zero".  Samuel  Palmisano will laugh all the way to the bank as he destroys this American icon.

- No work life balance.  I work at least 10 hours most days plus reply to email all weekend (as is expected by management).  Similarly, you are expected to check/reply to email and take meetings when you take a vacation day. The vacation time expires every year, so it's not like you can even bank the time when you have to work all day on vacation.   I have taken a lunch break less than 30 times total in the past 10 years.  I hear you have to actually book a meeting on your calendar in order to have time to step away to eat, instead of muting yourself on the phone meeting you've taken.

- Benefits have eroded over the years.  Our health insurance options are still decent but have gotten much more expensive, with higher deductibles and lesser coverage every single year.  This is particularly true for family coverage.  Many of us use our spouse's insurance if they work elsewhere.  Our 401k matching used to be great.  They have cut the matching in half and now only match at the end of the year. This means if they lay you off on Dec 30, you get nothing. (Yes, they did lay people off in December).  Quite a few people who are doing "good" but not stellar work have not seen a raise in 5+ years. 

- Constant layoffs. Of course it doesn't hit every business unit or every group every time, but we are always doing "Resource Actions."  As a manager, I have to constantly be prepared to submit names for upcoming RA's.  The RA's are NOT limited to low performers or areas where there has been a work reduction.  I'm supposedly in a growing part of the business, but the job growth is not in the US.  Despite what our CEO tells Trump or the media.

- I like the new performance review system in theory, but in practice assessments were handled poorly in 2016. We were strong armed into decreasing employee's ratings without any explanation of why or what the expectations were for average or above average ratings.  There is a disconnect as my team is viewed as high performing, but I'm not permitted to give them high performing ratings.  

- We are just wrapping up our bonus planning, which occurs once a year.  I was able to give 0.5%-1% bonuses to employees who were high performing.  It was the worst "bucket" I've ever seen, but not by much.  It's rare to get a bonus of more than a few thousand, no matter how good your results were.  Obviously, it's different for middle & upper management and for sales. 

- The scope of our jobs keeps changing and growing, because they lay off people and add those responsibilities to existing staff.  Currently, I'm doing the work that was spread across three people last year. (I was already pretty busy before this change). My story isn't unique.  There is little or no training when you are forced to assume responsibility for tasks that were previously not part of your job. 

- Lots of favoritism. I say this as someone who is seen as a top performer and a favorite! I've worked in four business units at IBM, and in each, upline management has a very obvious bias towards some employees and against others, which does not align with recent performance.   I also can't believe how much gossiping and in-fighting there is.  I get enough childishness from my children!  Who needs that at work?

- The "back to the office" movement is in full swing, as well as forced relocation.  Yes, getting to work from home at all was a perk, not a right, but it was very transparent, especially in management calls, that this was done to encourage attrition.  Not enough people quit because of this policy, they are now doing layoffs. 

- Constant "transformation" churn. Every year, our execs decide they are going to reinvent the wheel when it comes to internal processes.  Every year we waste tens of thousands of man hours pursuing these "transformation" projects that never actually result in any significant changes.  I'd welcome transformation if our executives were genuinely interested in it instead of just holding many, many meetings to talk about needing to transform.  

- "IBM - I've Been Meeting" - in management, you will spend the vast majority of time in meetings that could have been replaced with a quick email; meetings to discuss what to do in the other meeting about the same topic that day; etc.  We're terrible at collaborating.  Interestingly, despite so many meetings, most people I know at IBM have difficulty understanding and communicating what their organization's objectives and priorities are, as the information that trickles down from upper management is pretty limited.

- Mentoring is talked about constantly, and yet maybe 5% of the people I know at IBM have a mentor.   To be fair, most people don't have the time.  Similarly, we used to have a robust talent program where the top 5-10% of employees were groomed for more senior roles.  This was dismantled and the replacement feels very much like "you're on your own."

It is a financial engineering organization, it used to have monopoly for Systems, but this market is moving to cloud. 

As result, Board of Directors and Leadership are always inventing new ways to milk the money from stakeholders and clients.

1) Look at the Board of Directors: All of them from the old world of the traditional business and very few related to real tech business.

2) CEO and SVPs: Lou, Sam, Ginni and Arvind seem to be more concerned about their golden parachute. 

3 )Financial Engineering, the company sells services via GTS (Global Technology Services) - old tech and categorizes them as new tech - Cloud. I am concerned about SEC technical credibility and capability.

4) New initiatives: AI, Blockchain and other cutting edge product - when clients buy a large agreement (all you can eat buffet deal), IBM will add on a lot of cutting edge products. But in fact, these products do not work. They are a proof of concept for several years and goes nowhere. As result in the long run, IBM stream revenue only falls and many of the client's sponsors get fired for embracing the new.

5) Company only for white people: The only few colored people in leadership roles are to fulfill a quota. You will not see colored people at VP, GM or SVP roles managing large team and be responsible for key initiatives. Also, I had few cases of white women on leadership harassing myself and my teams for no reason, other than blaming the execution staff for poor performance - we quarterly overachieved our quota and had the top NPS scores in the region. These leaders stay in 2 years in a role, do a mess and than move on to the next role.

Poor salary is the top complaint at the site. Fresh graduates join despite the low pay in hope of a fat bonus (because IBM is a MNC!), only to realise the bonus is really, really, pathetic. Management and HR keeps doing "market surveys" to benchmark salaries, only to consistently adjust them to significantly below market. As a result, the mediocre and terrible stay and move around (even becoming managers), while the great people keep leaving. There are even those who endure the ridiculous salary for 1-2 years just so they can put the IBM name on their resume. 

The number of night conference calls are also frustrating. You are expected to take them to report status to your international counterparts. Some poor souls may take 4 night calls a week!

There are also a number of incompetent people who get lead/manager roles in the company because of the high turnover. They are the most experienced people who stay behind, but they consistently drag the teams down. Management does nothing to resolve this, and consistently reports to the execs that "things are great!".

Not sure where to start. Within Software sales division, IBM hired some 30 odd Hadoop Hunter Sales Engineer positions only to give them notices within 6 months. For the CEO/SVPs it seems like these are just "budget games". A VP comes up with the Hadoop Hunter idea and without any due diligence gets some $6-7MM sanctioned by the CEO. Then he hires Hadoop Sales Engineers only to lay them off in 5 months realizing that the product isn't selling.

So our Mr. VP still has his job and so do all the Hadoop Hunter managers. The same senior management is now seeking another $10MM from the CEO for the new so-called Open Source positions only to see them fail again in 6 months time. These executives take fun in playing with our lives. Personally I am okay but I know an engineer has a baby on the way, another person is delivering kids to college and so on but for those executives and managers, these are just Budget Games or SYA Games. What a shame!! Not a single manager in the hadoop hunter team got a notice, however all new technical folks who never got a chance to prove themselves are being laid off.

The flip side of working from home is that there is no work-life balance.  In fact prior to leaving IBM, they changed the term Work-Life Balance to Work-Life Integration.  There is no balance at all.  IBM will grind you to a nub for wages far less than industry standard.  The focus on EPS has caused a cutback on everything.  For example, The allocation for expenses has become even more of a joke now that I have left.  When I was at IBM the per diem for food in NYC was $50 - that might get you a decent lunch.  Now, IBM even pro-rates the per diem based on when you leave your house.

If you have a family and your family will be relying on you to provide insurance, run away as fast as you can.  The amount that people have to pay for family coverage is outrageous (although single coverage wasn't too bad when I left in 2011)

The thinking behind and implementation of the ineffective and destructive performance review process is supposed to be changing this year.  The challenge for the management team will be how to effectively change the thinking behind the old approach to performance review, with it's focus on "distributions" or quotas. This thinking is very ingrained in our corporate culture. Sadly, the previous system was build on outright untruths formally perpetuated by the management team, such as, "There is no quota system.", which is legendary within IBM. You cannot build a team when staff are effectively played off against each other to improve their "relative contribution".  This would be at the heart of why staff avoid taking on projects with inherent risk because they are afraid of being punished if they don't achieve an aggressive goal by loosing their meager pay increase, being ranked lower, and possibly becoming the target of a layoff.

I was with the company for 10 years and saw the culture erode signficantly from high employee morale to low. The job I took after leaving IBM was a 50% improvement in compensation and this isn't uncommon. The issue is that they've cut so much cost out of the business trying to march to their Earnings per Share roadmap that it has had a far reaching effect on the allowable operating expenditure of the various business units. This translates into promotions being few and far between, measly compensation and raises and extenuating circumstances required to attend education or conferences that involve travel. The culture is also quite hierarchical vs. collegial and egalitarian.

Where the company needs to improve is investing in its Optometry Personnel. There seems to be a "fear" of making the commitment of taking the established optometrists out of their test room environment and developing them into people leaders of there top stores. There is a huge wealth of knowledge contained within these personnel with all the skills already there to be developed further with ease but for some reason nobody ever seems to act on it properly. Instead the general approach tends to be to invest in external retail based candidates or pharmacy colleague's to lead and manage the practice's. All that really does is create a lack of empathy and understanding between colleagues.  " it's easier to teach an optometrist retail than a retailer optometry "

There is a real opportunity to invest in optometrists career journey in this company and differentiate themselves from there competitors as employer of choice. They are already beating others with pay structure and clinical environment, if they nail this they will be onto something special. 

P.s. I am not an optometrist

pros:
Compared to the other networks (they call themselves a partnership but are a financial advice network) They provide a high level of product support and training.

Could be a good learning experience prior to joining a more solid firm.
cons:
They strip out all digital marketing for themselves and train you to use expensive methods which last worked in the 90s. You are essentially responsible for producing revenue/fees. They restrict you from using many methods from developing business and essentially you are marketing their brand for free. If you leave, generally, they keep your clients due to high exit charges which mean you cannot advise them to leave.

They usually pay no salaries and all the risk and expense is borne by yourself as a wealth adviser. If they paid salaries their whole business model would break, essentially it has echos of the pyramid/MLM model of the 90s.

The other thing they like to do is absorb the client banks of smaller IFAs who join them.

Change is necessary. But managing the change is equally necessary. Failing site of managing change with the poor communication is leading to key people leaving plus customers leaving. After all the change: what will you be left with? Such a shame as the position in marketplace was strong, work ethic was great and the core foundations for a strong enterprise in agile markets were there but amongst the desires and vision the company has lost site of what’s important it’s staff and it’s customers. Surprised Grainger have not picked up on this, nor hr. surely they have a role to play in questioning this.  Otherwise how are they being responsible stewards.  I did not leave as a result of these issues but due to personal circumstances but would have left due to all of these

I know that methods will change and people will have to adapt, but the problem is the staff were not given the plan. Having worked at  Cromwell for many years, seeing the 2 corner shops turn into a multi million £ turnover, it just seemed sad to see so many good staff leave. The high number does seem to indicate that there was something wrong in explaining how the changes would take place. The quality of staff they had (and still have) would surely have seen the light, if they were given a torch of hope. In the past how many staff left, very few. All though MG's 'ways' could well been now seen as out of date in this new world, but his enthusiasm pulled us all along. The one thing I don't want is for Cromwell to fail, as it would be a shame to lose the great customer base that was given and the great staff. The biggest problem was the staff did not know what was really happening, so this could not be explained to the customers. Again, I do hope Grainger/Cromwell do succeed, as it would be a testament to all those extra hours we all worked in the early days. I just feel the transition period could have done much better with more transparency, which would then have not produced all the negative reviews. Anyway good luck, and enjoy the ride.

Progression is near impossible unless you are a star. Long term better to exit to smaller firms for greater flexibility and responsibility.

- No sense of teamwork among team members: associates tend to become good teammates, but there is a gap between them and partners. You often feel like you work “for someone and their goals” instead of “with someone towards a common goal.” This is made clear to you with passive agressive comments when partners get stressed. 
- Very clear favoritism by the managing partner of certain employees. This sets bad precedent for the rest of the partnership to behave in the same way. 
- No proper work assignment system in corporate. 
- No cohesion in associate development between groups within the corporate umbrella. 
- No proper database for corporate precedent. 
- Fear of giving real feedback about superiors when asked: people tend to not say what they think about bad leaders/managers even in “anonymized reviews”. 
- No proper integration of new lateral hires. You see all these new faces walking around but no one bothered to introduce them and welcome them to the firm. 
- Focus on litigation and arbitration training and lack of focus on corporate.

Managers are not at all transparent

- Widespread incompetence from Agent level through to Senior Management with 'politics' and toxic employees a constant threat, specifically...
- Senior Management are forced to manipulate end of year PDR ratings for their Managers and Agents in order to satisfy the 'bonus pot' restrictions
- Poor decision-making at Senior Management level with regular conflicts of interest presented due to 'personal' managerial relationships, including work delegation, award nominations and bonus payments.
- Valid and substantiated concerns regarding Senior Management behaviour raised via the formal Corporate Whistle-Blower process are devalued and dismissed without investigation.
- Stress and anxiety levels within Management Team are un-welcome and unsupported with decisions made often based on political and self-gain.
- Despite being well publicised and actively encouraged throughout the rest of the business, Flexible Working (BWOW) is not welcome or allowed 
- The Sickness Management and Absence Policy is open to interpretation and applied inconsistently, again driven by popularity and friendships

The company shows more than actually it represents, lives inside, there is a big mess on several areas. Lot of internal politics

Work environment: 

- The computer systems were rubbish and half the computers didn't work. One manager admitted the computers were as old as 10 years

- They also had a hot desk policy so there were no dedicated seats and this made the environment tense as some people would get annoyed if someone sat in their usual seat or if a computer was out of order, seating spaces would be limited (though management would completely disagree with you on that).

- The desks were close together so you could see what the person next to you is doing. No privacy whatsoever.

- KPIs/Call stats: Extreme and unachievable. You were only allowed to be in personal for 5 minutes a day. You could only be in ACW for 3 minutes a day. If you were late going on your breaks because you were stuck on a call, it would mess up your adherence levels and management would get funny with you about it.

Management: 

- The managers in the department were horrible people. If they didn't like you, they would make your life difficult and conspire against you. 

- They never support their teams and if a customer wants to speak to a manger they will begrudge you for it or in most instances refuse to take the call and ask us to tell the customer they'll get a call back (which probably never happened) and they would condemn work/call avoidance on us when they probably do it themselves.

Great management team, supportive colleagues and a dynamic can-do culture. I've worked for a number of companies and Access is up there with the very best. The way the firm has managed the Covid19 crisis has been exceptional
Love Work Love Life Access

Business Honesty is a real positive for access, they are open with their employees about how the company is doing. Granted there is some inherent biased towards this from my perspective as i have so far only experienced the company doing well. 
The difference between Access and other companies from my experience is that with Access you can see the changes being made to continually adapt and grow within the market. 
They respect and listen to their employees, might seem like a given but Access has really grasped the concept that their is a vital difference between a 'Manager' and a 'Leader'. 
Over recent years more and more companies have changed to the same approach as socialised programs in that a certain Post is aligned with a certain set salary or hourly rate irrelevant of the productive output of each individual.
Definitely a positive for me is that Access have not followed this path, they have stuck to the core principle of how a business actually works as opposed to a Utopian view that everyone should be paid the same regardless of productivity. So with Access the more productive you are is directly reflected by pay increases and bonuses. 
As mentioned they are focused on providing a quality leadership for employees and this again is not just a tag line, working day to day within the Access group is a pleasant and relaxed experience, i personally feel comfortable asking for assistance from both colleagues and big wigs. 

Overall i would definitely recommend Access as a place to work for people from all levels of experience. They are willing to invest time and money into individuals to train them so don't let a lack of technical knowledge hold you back.

You are expected to work hard but supported throughout. Salaries are competitive, benefits are great! Personally I know if I continue to work hard I will be rewarded and believe the company will support me with my career progression.

I'm really impressed with the way Access have dealt with COVID19, we were all working from home within 48 hours and just recently a few of our offices opened on a phased approach. Staff were asked to volunteer to assist with this programme, whilst the rest of us carried on 'business as usual' from home. 

We are kept up to date with regular video messages from our Board of Directors and I have a daily video meeting with my team (which have certainly kept my spirits up). 

I'm proud to be working for such a vibrant and forward thinking company and am looking forward to what the future brings.
cons: The only thing that springs to mind is that as the business grows, I know less people - maybe I should spark a conversation next time I see a new face at the coffee machine

I worked there for over twenty years. I found management to be reasonable and were always sympathetic and supportive through a serious health issue I had. Staff at head office were exceptional. cons: Mmmm where to start???? They will happily have staff working 60 hours a week, they don't pay people correctly, eg not at correct rate, not for correct number of hours, sometimes both or not at all! Wages department treat you with contempt when you do question it.... that's if they get around to answering your phone call.... Oh yeah, you dont even receive a pay slip sometimes so v difficult to actually see where they've made the mistakes! They bang on about "Person Centeredness" like they invented it but do little to model this ethos, eg, managers will ammend care plans to reflect what is best for the company, NOT for the service users they claim to put at the centre of their own care. If Staff try to stand up for their own, or the Service Users' rights they are quickly stamped on by Managers. Safeguarding issues brought to Managers' attention are also dismissed. It goes on and on, which is why i left, and why I wrote to the CQC about them. Them simply must be stopped because they are not fit for purpose.

pros: Having previously worked at another UK high street bank in a corporate role I agreed to join Metro Bank because of the AMAZEING culture that is being built by the management team and all colleagues. The people really make this as a business. Everyone has a can do attitude and a willingness to do what is right for the customer. After 8 years of 'No we cant do that, it is outside of policy' the two to say no attitude is very refreshing. I have worked in the business for 18 months now and all colleagues have been very welcoming from day 1. The facilities within the business are excellent with investment clearly made in property. Management are very supportive of development opportunities and plans are clearly structured to help you progress through the business.
There is a strong emphasis on a really positive culture at Metro. People really do try to help each other out.
I have worked for metro bank for 5 years and I can honestly say that there is no other company quite like it. It's a fun filled environment bringing laughter to the table.
Everyone is really nice to each other.

Constantly growing business which creates a lot of opportunities but as someone else mentioned, Metro Bank is not the right place for passengers. If you are looking to progress, you need to work for it, it won't just be handed to you because you have done your time, and unfortunately a lot of ppl join because they think they will get promoted quickly. there are so many great opportunities within the bank. As long as you work hard for it. Craig is an amazing asset to Metro. I have never worked for a bank before but I can tell you, his involvement with all of the colleagues across the business is great. How many ppl can say they see their CEO actively involved in the business day in and day out. His passion is admirable. His dedication to Metro Bank is amazing and inspirational. I consider myself lucky to be working with him.
The people and team are great, loads of opportunity for growth if you know the right people

Metro bank is one of the best places I've worked so far. Several opportunities to grow and develop within the bank with support if you need it. Honestly I've not met even one colleague who was not helpful in any store or department.

The culture of putting customers first is so important and must be maintained. Our customers love our professional, friendly and knowledgeable service. We don't get commission or any sales targets. We just do whats right for the customer.

Our 'Bump it up' mentality is amazing (being able to ask anyone, anywhere in the company for help) and must carry on. These allow us to best serbe our customers and change silly banking rules. This is what sets us apart from the competition.

Working in store is generally very relaxed. The colleagues you work with have a similar mentality of friendliness (I do question some people's ability in the job however).

The progression is good. New stores are opening all the time so new positions open up all the time. Theres opportunity to move to other departments too.
There are many courses you can get on to to expand your role. 
There are fast track programmes to business managers etc.

Private pension, health cover, 2nd opinion on doctors, Bike2work, free opticians, free flu shots, Vitality, cheap gym membership, Share scheme. All very good and helps a lot.

American Express is a great brand that treats its customers very well. I learned a lot about all the factors to be considered when launching a new customer experience or product. I was happy with my pay even though some people complained about it not being competitive to the New York market rate. Obviously it's not competitive if you're comparing it to investment banking, but I thought it was very competitive to market rate. Work life balance was great and there was a high degree of ownership. The company also encourages you to move around and explore other areas of the business, so it's a great way to explore other interests (e.g. if you're in finance and want to move into digital product management, if you're in New York and want to explore a career overseas). There are also lots of interest groups and activities that the company promotes to encourage personal and professional growth.

American Express pays well (I was making 16.94 an hour starting pay plus up to $1000 in bonus per month), they have great health, dental, and even legal insurance, and amazing 401K plan with employer contributions up to 5% match and 4 weeks paid vacation starting (bank holidays are not given if you want them you have to book them using your 4 weeks.

American Express really values its employees.  There are opportunities to grow and develop, especially if you seek them.

American Express has strong core values and the leadership team live by them.

Compensation is comparable to other companies.  Maybe a little better...Benefits include medical, dental, vision insurance, 401K, profit sharing and a generous package of personal time off.  Employees are even allowed to purchase a week of vacation!

Telecomuting is an option in many areas of the company.

Skill and style of leadership varies.  But, generally, leadership is adequate.

Senior company leaders are doing a good job leading the company through these hard economic times.  Yes, there have been some layoffs.  But, overall, they were handled with a high degree of sensitivity and the severance packages are better than some from other companies.

Times are tough and so is American Express!

1. The culture here is absolutely incredible. I love working for a company where I am encouraged to be authentic and myself. 
2. I love the people I work with, they are all intelligent in their own ways and the company respects different ideas from different people
3. Diversity is a core concept as well as empowering minorities and people who might not have had a voice in the business world 20 years ago. 
4. The benefits are incredible and are available when you start on day 1.
5. The pay is competitive and makes me feel valued. I get constant feedback and am able to search and see any salay within the company for any position in general.
6. There is TONS of opportunity for growth. As someone who joined the company as a Platinum Customer Care professional 5 years ago, I've been able to attain several different positions based on the internal hiring process. 
7. Senior leadership is absolutely amazing. I love working for the senior leaders and hope to become one myself one day.
8. Work/life balance is very nice here. They are very understand when you have emergencies and depending on your position, they can allow you to work from home when needed.
9. The CEO is also absolutely amazing. Steve has such a healthy vision for where he wants the company to be from an employee standpoint and I hope that he continues to do a wonderful job as our CEO.

American Express has agressive goals (this is both good and bad).  It is good as it challenges employees to grow.  However, it makes work/life balance difficult if not impossible to acheive.  Leaders talk about the importance of work/life balance.  But, in practice, most people work 50 hours per week or more.

Another, down side of American Express, is that many jobs are being moved out of the US.  This may keep the company strong, but, it is difficult for employees.  Every year, more and more people are let go in the US.  

The compensation package and benefits are also being scaled back.  Each year, employees bear more of the cost for insurance.  This year, due to the bad economy, the company is no longer matching employee contributions to the 401K.  

Times are tough and so is American Express!

I found that people were often too nice and would avoid confrontation at all costs. The result is that sometimes the culture feels passive aggressive and people spend a lot of time trying to build consensus vs. working on the actual project. Since it's a heavily regulated industry, things move quite slow and they're late to adopt new technologies. Once you get to a certain level, it's nearly impossible to get promoted because there are so few positions open at the VP level, especially if you're outside of New York. Organizational changes are common; during my tenure there, I've seen entire teams being restructured when they thought they had just started on an initiative that leadership cared about. The whole time I was there, I felt that there was very little clarity about the vision and the strategy, how my work was contributing to the overall business goals and objectives beyond the immediate customer impact of my work, and I felt that people promoted to leadership positions were not necessarily great leaders (which is common in other companies too, I'm sure).

Game of Thrones level politics, complete with factions, cliques, alliances.  It's the worst at the VP level - those trying to make it, those trying to keep it.  It's a huge distraction to the people who are simply trying to do a good job, work smart, improve our products, and do what's right for the customers.

A few downsides to working at American Express are: 1) the call center environment can be an absolute nightmare (like most call centers) while I was working there I developed so much stress that I gained 70 pounds in a year and some other serious health conditions including heart-burn, depression, anxiety and back pain (the chair they provide you can be very uncomfortable) 2) Your leaders say that they care about you, that they think about you and how they can help you and that they "don't care about the numbers" and that they "just want to make sure you are happy here" but that's a total lie, my wife and I both worked there and we both had the same experience, Team Leaders that would tell you one thing and then talk about you behind your back. They would say how great you're doing and then complain to their leaders about how their team doesn't do well. So all in all the leadership could be better. 3) Trying to get promoted or move to a different department is near to impossible. I knew people that had been "on the floor" for 3+ years and had been trying to get into a different department but couldn't. Let's just say it pays to have friends in high places at American Express.

Throughout the Covid-19 pandemic, I have been continuously wowed at how important 'doing the right thing' really is to Taylor Wimpey. 

Employees and customers have consistently been at the forefront of decisions made by our senior leaders. This was clear from the start of this uncertain time when they made the decision to be the first housebuilder to shut our sites when no one else was brave enough, right through to the discount that is now being offered to NHS staff/keyworkers in order to show our thanks. 

As an employee who was furloughed I have consistently been kept updated and engaged with what is happening in the business, both through my immediate team mates and the wider communications shared by our CEO. 

I am really proud and extremely grateful to work for a company that consistently surprises me (in a good way) and is always trying to do, not what is easy, but what is right!
A great place to work - focussed on conducting business in the right way with all our customers and employees at the heart of everything we do. A business that is a vehicle for all your ambitions.

Being in the Army is obviously tough, both mentally and physically. Long working hours, lots of time away from home is this era of dynamic warfare and the inherent danger make this a single persons job. A lot of personnel are happily married, however, so don't let this put you off, it's just a big strain on relationships due to the time spent apart and the way in which it happens.

The biggest downside is money. As a helicopter pilot with full training behind me and operational on our latest attack helicopter, I was earning about 60% of the average civilian pilots pay. With so much extra training, long working hours, extra responsibility in carrying weapons and the obvious danger that entails, this should be addressed as for me personally, this was the main reason I departed for brighter shores-I literally was struggling to make ends meet. To put it bluntly, a mediocre car sales person would earn more than I did fighting for my country.

This was my first job just after turning 16, and it left a horrible taste so to speak. It started off great, having been raised with LEGO with Danish family roots I had high expectations. I was blissfully unaware of how much harassment I was getting until later on.

My first day of "training" (Which was just silence in the back room while taking a digital online training course) I was privy to seeing my assistant manager barge into the back room, raging mad, and kicking/throwing boxes down the back hall. This was not uncommon later on, he was constantly raging due to interactions with customers.

Within the first 2 weeks of working there, red flags were already popping up. One female co-worker constantly and purposefully ignored me, only ever talking to me when she wanted me to do her work instead of herself, or if she wanted to poke fun at me for being a vegetarian. Another female co-worker (who was later promoted to supervisor) made the remark of "I'm going to whip out my [male genitalia] and smack you with it." (reminder, I was a minor at the time and this woman was mid-twenties.) The co-workers were very cliquey and would take any chance they could to exclude me.

One co-worker turned supervisor, reported me and 2 other of my co-workers for having a conversation about Star Wars because she had no knowledge of the subject and took offense to that.

My hellish manager, constantly pretended to hit or kick me, admitted openly that he used me as a scapegoat, and tried to embarrass me on any possible occasion.

Among many other harassment and mistreatment instances that I'm unable to recall at the moment, they also all partook in violation of company policies, such as:

Discluding me from Christmas decorating by sending me home; Making me change very high lightbulbs on a wobbly ladder without supervision; Stealing bricks and minifigs; Intentionally damaging sets from shipments so they could then purchase said sets at a discounted price; Using inappropriate language in the store and back room; Having inappropriate music playing in the back room; Having inappropriate screensavers on company phones left lying in the store; and more.

Aside from my store itself, I also dealt with mistreatment from Corporate. I had reported my co-workers for how they were behaving and corporate investigated. They ended up telling me nobody had broken any rules, nobody would be fired, that I was a liar, that nobody was harassing me, and that I was the one causing problems. Even though I had been tearing up while conversing with them and I was a minor at 16, they did nothing. I quit promptly on the spot a few minutes later.

Aside from my personal experiences I was also told stories by co-workers of people who worked there prior to me:

One old employee urinated in another co-worker's drinking cup because they had ticked him off; Another employee had called 'dibs' on girls who he said were 'gonna be hot when they're older'; another used to hit on all the Asian girls who came in including one of the co-workers.

I also had co-workers and supervisors  who quit from mistreatment. A newer co-worker had also commented on how it seemed everyone constantly bullied me.

About 7 months later I heard that a new store was opening in San Francisco, and I thought it could be a fresh start. I wrote to my old regional manager and got the go ahead to apply. I applied, got a call back maybe the next day and the manager I spoke with loved my prior experience and was ready to offer me a supervisor position, he said he'd be in touch after checking with my last manager to see what he had to say about me. About a few days later there was a job fair for the store so I dropped by and left my application with the people there as well who also loved my prior experience and such, and they too wanted to see what my previous manager had to say about me. They told me to watch for a call in the next couple of days. I never heard from any of them again, even after writing an email to them to check up on the hiring process.
The working environment is great.

There can be some pressure at times (not as bad as most places though!), and you probably won't be able to get access to any type of truly fun job (to make a career of like being a  builder, etc) from working in a retail store.

I kind of fell into Unity on my way out of the VFX industry. It's like night and day... a work environment that fosters creativity and technical excellence, but understands that the goal is to get tools into artists hands. The "democratizing game development" philosophy comes from inside Unity and is practiced daily at all levels. 

I've never been treated so well as an employee.

Some of the core values Unity tries to embrace are "Best Idea Wins", "Go Bold" and "In It Together". I've worked at many companies whose values are allegedly good, but don't actually take action on them. In contrast, Unity seems to really invest in these ideas. They deliver Active Listening training to leaders. They have a whole range of social events. They even have an entire Wellbeing team dedicated to running clubs and socials, sending gifts, and so on (so these responsibilities don't fall on the shoulders of people who are juggling this with other work)! They also have several Employee Resource Groups for people in marginalised groups (like a BIPOC one, an LGBTQ+ one, a women's ERG, and so on). Sustainability is also a core concern, with much discussion and events happening around that.

Every team is managed differently, so your experience may vary, but I am given lots of freedom to shape my job to fit myself, rather than change myself to fit the role. I can explore different technologies, collaborate across the organisation, and get involved in a wide variety of work.

The work is interesting and generously compensated (both in terms of salary and holiday allowance); the people are brilliantly smart, talented, and excellent listeners; and the technology is cutting-edge and exciting to work with. It's the most positive and inspirational workplace I've ever had the pleasure of working at.
Exciting prospects for the future.
empowering, smart people. fun, challenging, self-driven

Even with all the recent growth Unity is still in it's infancy of ideas, processes and systems. So joining the company allows you to utilize all your strengths and truly make an impact. Plus the visibility that leadership provides into the direction of the company is refreshing. I've never seen C-Suite leaders openly engage in discussion/debate with all employees about product ideas, roadmap etc. Keep it up!

- Intelligent people (with great sense of humor)
- Lunch and snacks included
- Interesting projects
- Flexible work hours with capability to work from home 2 days a week
cons: Not much, so far so good.

Employees who can take charge and work well from their own initiative will thrive here. Unity does not operate with the rigid constraints and processes you may find at other large organizations. This may be challenging to some people who look for a more structure.
Politics heavy and constant organizational shifts.
The process of getting code into the final product can sometimes be frustrating, but the end result is usually better quality, so in the end, it's worth it.
Compensation and Merit (totals) and process is okay but needs improvement.
Upper management seems to be currently shifting/changing, and these moves affect the concentration and focus of their direct teams.

Sometimes too many meetings, especially during the pandemic (as it's a big organisation).

If you're not from a corporate background, the jargon can be off-putting. There is a jargon glossary though!

Many different systems for different tasks. Not a huge problem, just a lot to learn when you first arrive.

Sometimes things are moving so fast, it feels as if we haven't finished one product/solution before we're working on or shipping the next one, which can damage credibility with users (e.g. if something ships with bugs)

- Filter out all the fake reviews that are obviously posted by recruiters trying to bank some commission. There are lots of them and they are not accurate portrayal of what's going on inside Unity.

- Low caliber talent pool. Unity is desperate for coders and the hiring bar has suffered as a result of that. It's hard to count on people to get their stuff done. 

- Performance review is extremely unstructured. It's very hard to take perf review seriously at Unity. Whatever you say will go unnoticed and it seems to have no effect towards compensation.

- Low caliber managers. Anyone .... literally anyone can become a manager at Unity. If you want a 'lead' title, Unity shall provide. If you suck, no worries there is no consequence. You can always revert back to IC.

- Last but not least, if you are financially motivated. This is not the place for you. No target bonus. Compensation change is rare and stock package is a joke.

Long hours and insane expectations. Office is mostly empty after 5P but Slack is active 24/7. Comparable to working at an investment bank.

With so much growth there has been a certain level of friends hiring friends. While referrals are great if too much overlap is done when hiring it can start to create an alienating environment for others.

- Company values are BS and not implemented nor demonstrated by management in any credible way.
- The company claims to be inclusive, flat, and bottom-up, but it clearly has a shadow structure of people who are making top-down decisions.
- Sexism is prevalent.
- The Old Guard holds too much power and is unwilling to accept new ideas coming from others, e.g. new hires.
- The strategy is all over the place and completely devoid of focus. 
- Code quality is alarmingly bad. 
- Comp is a joke and has been an issue for ages.

1. Inhumane working hours - staff work more than 16 hours per day continuously over a few months, including weekends and public holidays, during the peak period. No time off in lieu is given.

2. Poor eAudIT software - extremely buggy, constantly hangs, and reduces staff efficiency by 50% or more.

3. Lack of control over quality of work - most of the time, staff have to follow-up on incomplete and poorly done work by another staff member. 

4. Lack of control in planning for personal commitments - as a junior staff member, you are not told in advance when you have to work late. You are expected to always be available to work overtime when needed.

5. High turnover rate with a lack of effort to replace staff during critical periods - remaining staff get squeezed to the limit as they take on the workload of resignees. They eventually quit and a vicious cycle ensues. 

6. Unable to enjoy Christmas (you will most likely be working) and New Year's Eve/Day (you will most likely be plotted on a stock-take).

7. No time to participate in the activities and courses organised by the Rec Club

8. Poor compensation relative to working hours - no overtime pay, no 13th months bonus, variable bonus for the last financial year was a mere 1.5 months. A 4.6% firm-wide pay-cut was carried out in 2011 to 2012.

1. Study package for ACA delivered by BPP is predominantly delivered remotely, the first face to face college time I had was a year into the training programme. Therefore college time does not also involve developing relationships with colleagues, for many trainees this is a large pull for the job.  
2.  Lack of support for study from engagement managers - many instances of not being given the timetabled study time for the ACA.  Often being told you have too much study for exams the manager thinks are easy (in many instances the manager has completed a different qualification, not the ACA, so do not know what the exams entail).  
3. No work/life balance - most weeks from September to April/May have been 60 hours at least, mainly due to a lack of headcount in the department.
4. Lack of variety for trainees - many trainees stay on the same client for 3 years.  Give trainees a rounded experience of different departments and different industries, this may help retention rates.

In our Roanoke office, there have been two rounds of cuts, the second round just happened, which directly affected me. My internal evaluations were significantly better than others that I've started with in the same position, but those people are still there. Although this is a small firm, you definitely feel the sense of politics in play. They don't care about how well you work, only how much upper management in the company like you. This is obviously something common in the consulting industry, but the fact that people get laid off without reason, even though they are hard working individuals disappoints me. Afterward, I hear that people weren't laid off due to performance, but because we just weren't needed anymore due to the types of services the firm was trying to sell.

I was extremely loyal to the firm, and did not attempt to get other jobs even though head hunters were contacting me every other week -- this got me nowhere, and now I am stuck without a job in economic turmoil. We had no idea we were getting laid off, it just happened out of nowhere.

If you're good with office politics, this may be a great place for you, but otherwise I'd stray away, as the firm will get rid of you once they've milked you for all you're worth.

Where to begin:
-The pay is below average. You work long hour days and the amount for which you are getting paid is less than someone working as a Dental Assistant for $15 an hour. That is when you think about the amount per hours you put in slaving.
-The office politics...atrocious. Managers/Sr. Managers/Partners have favorites. That is a blessing and a curse. A blessing, because these people will speak highly of you. A curse, because now, you're the go to for everything, causing you to be over-worked and stressed out. Meanwhile, the average good performer to low performers have less work to do, and the balance is completely off.
-This company lays off people at will; yet they cannot explain how they determined which individuals to get rid of. They will do this towards the end of busy season, right after you spent the last 3.5 months trying to make them happy and get the tax and audit work done.
-There is no work-life balance, especially for people with families. The job comes first before your family and that is a sacrifice you are supposed to make. 
-They talk about the flexibility of being able to not just work in the office; however, if you work from home, they still judge you, regardless if you are actually completing your work. 
-It is supposed to be a team environment, but there are several instances where people get thrown under the bus...in most cases when it is not their fault.
-There should be a standard procedure for each engagement...but there seems to be managers who like to have their own preferences; therefore, expect to do your work in 10 different ways to please all of these people. 
-One of the pros was that they pay for your CPA exam. Well, good luck studying for it while working here. 
-There is zero upper management transparency. You tell them issues with the firm and they do not respond with an effective solution. 
-HR here is a joke. The professionalism and the protocols in which they do things needs to be reevaluated ASAP.
-This new "rebranding"...it's kind of failing. No one really recognizes the name RSM as much as they recognized McGladrey.

pros:
Graduate management programme quite well structured and developed over the years - still people with the company who joined the programme 10+ years previously - excellent programme for exposing you to the larger and more important functions of a business.  

Plenty of emphasis placed on the cohort of management graduates allowing for plenty of exposure to the senior people of the business.

Plenty of different work that the company has won/acquired and if you're forward thinking grants plenty of opportunity to move around and experience different types of infrastructure servicing, operations, consulting etc. 

Generally the people are hard-working and seem to have a lot of passion & time for the company and the senior management, nice to know the upper part of the business tends to have the welfare and development of their employees on their agenda.

I can't speak of any FO jobs, but from what I've observed in MO/BO arena, it's chaotic, to put it mildly. The company is trying to reform their IT infrastructure, but as an industry leading "abuser" of outsourcing, it's once again outsourcing away its IT problems by creating IT centers in places where it is not known for IT. 
IT is just an epitome of where DB's BO/MO currently stands at. Every function is intertwined with outsourcing and core locations, and there is no accountability for quality and consistency in the process. Instead of trying to gain efficiency from where the work really happens, DB just allocates work to places where it shouldn't mainly for cost reasons. This makes the structure more complicated and more bloated, and therefore, more costly. Also, even those functions that are seen as "grunt works" have their value, and by outsourcing away those functions, it loses a positive feedback loop. For example, juniors in NY or elsewhere won't be equipped with necessary skills or knowledge to perform their jobs as they should. In essence, too much compartmentalization and slicing and dicing of functions are becoming a new religion managers are worshiping these days at the bank. This will make them look busy and have achieved something, and thereby even enabling them to become MDs, but this doesn't benefit anybody in the end. 
There are also so many middle managers (i.e., AVP to directors) in the process who just sit idly by the problems until they are forced to fix the problems. There are many good guys, but there are contemptible managers who just want to keep their jobs. 
Finally, just to offer my 2 cents on their geographic focus, I think the bank's direction is dead wrong. The bank's "firm" commitment in certain European regions is just digging a deeper hole to its problem. What they have contemplated under the 2020 strategy is essentially shedding growth regions and sticking to regions where the situation will only get worse.
The company is going through several regional and international changes that can make job certainty and or long term planning difficult for an employee's career.

It’s a unique place to work and the location in central London is superb for access to all the other galleries and museums in Mayfair and St James’. 

The company objectives are very clear and I learned so many skills that I have taken forward in my career. It's a very corporate culture, but in hindsight I learned a lot about what makes a company successful in an increasingly challenging and complex art market. I had a lot of autonomy in the role.

The company works hard to engage with staff and get employees to meet each other, such as at the 1766 monthly drinks events. The Christmas and summer parties are great fun and well organised. Staff development through apps is pretty cool and there are so many training opportunities, social events and lunchtime lectures that really do enhance the experience of working in the company. Training happens both on and offsite and managers encouraged us to do this as part of our professional development. This certainly isn’t the case in many other companies. The IT provision (iPhones, apps) is great and there is a strong company ethos that I really liked.
You will be working with some of the best in the business
Opportunities to learn from specialists
Incredibly interesting company to work for, being surrounded by a constantly rotating selection of the world's most beautiful objects is really inspiring.
Amazing and talented specialists, many curatorial geniuses
Exposure to art masterpieces, many colleagues are dedicated and knowledgable.
Nice staff and nice to work for
cons: Low salary as it is the minimum wage
Hierarchal, borderline abusive to staff, lack of respect

- Reorganization happens on a seemingly annual basis - managers and directors get shuffled around to different business units, while individual contributors get laid off (although severance packages are generous)
- Promotions can be difficult to obtain, at least at the individual contributor/lower management level.  At the same time, remaining in the same position for longer than a few years is a bad idea, as it can give the impression that you aren't interested in taking on new challenges and potentially target you for the next round of layoffs.  You must aggressively seek out your own career development and network with the right people within the company, in order to move ahead.
- Innovation and creativity can be stifled by layers of regulatory, quality and security control

How long have I got?
- Long hours - absolutely no work life balance
- Projects are poorly staffed and not scoped realistically, placing a huge amount of pressure on these left to deal with the mess 
- Lean business model has resulted in every person being stretched to breaking point to deliver to plans and costs which are completely unrealistic
- The company promotes itself as highly focussed on training and development. However, resources are so thinly stretched that you work in constant "fire fight mode" without any time for training or support from senior management to develop and deliver
- The complete abdication of responsibility from senior executives (at least 80% of those I have worked with do not support staff or provide adequate direction), but place huge pressure on all levels below to do their jobs for them
- Performance management and promotion system does not work. Like with every consultancy, playing the political game is key to success - but the ability to get promoted / pay is not commensurate with effort and ability

* Use old technology (was on Windows XP up until a year ago).
* Very little career progression.
* Decision makers (i.e CEO/CFO/CIO) have no contact with those on the front line.
* Focus is given to the sales function. Huge divide between the way that the sales side and central functions are treated.
* Rewards and incentives are all for recruitment consultants, not central functions. The only benefit available to all employees, including central function is'YouChoose' which offers products which Hays claim to be at discounted rates, however cheaper alternatives are always found. Central functions do not get entry into holiday draws etc.
* Very little changes, despite asking.
Pay is low, favoritism, no structure

-Below market rate base salaries
-Minimal meaningful benefits, even at manager/ senior manager level
-Hays publish a lot of thought leadership for their clients around retaining talent with regards to salary, benefits and culture etc however they do not apply the same logic to their own workforce
-Goal posts for promotion targets are inconsistent
-Staff turnover high and limited ability to change the vicious circle due to lack of decision making power at a local level
-Flexible working is limited
-Recent changes made to flex dress code but still overly and unnecessarily corporate, often having to earn dress down days rather than being respected and trusted to dress appropriately where necessary and act accordingly. 
-All of this resulting in quality consultants going elsewhere in order to be rewarded more competitively and work in a modern environment
-Investment in appropriate training as you develop through the business drys up
-Far too much time spent on encouraging consultants to do more and more (KPI hell) rather than focusing on quality
-The commission structure is not set up to support associates make a worthwhile amount of commission in their first year, particularly on a temp desk. So be prepared to live off your low base salary for some time!
-Even with an influx of resignations, the root cause of the unhappy  workforce is often not addressed instead the revolving door starts again and more people are hired. In most cases the problem is the Director leading the office or the manager of the team. 
-Hours are long, which personally I'm not afraid of, however Directors are reluctant to get their hands dirty whilst managers are away on annual leave, meaning little rest bite. 
- Far too many underhand counter offers at the point of resignation
- Salary too low for an internship considering the amount of hours you do in a week.

Chaotic - HSBC is still incredibly disjointed, with basic systems not working, PC's crashing and not even having functioning lifts and building passes (this was none other than Head Office!)

Culture - HSBC is still in the dark ages with how it operates.  There is a clear divide between Junior Management (G4) and those beneath within departments.  There are clear themes of nepotism which breeds only a shielded culture and no openness or willingness to admit fault.  

Competencies - Unfortunately, a lot of staff are not equipped to work within the sector.  Hires are usually based upon whom managers personally like as opposed to just capability based therefore staff are generally within their 40's as an average and not exactly dynamic & challenging.  This unfortunately maintains the same poor standard and people do not think, they just do.

Progression - forget about it.  Speak to any former employee and they will repeat that there is a glass ceiling; Junior/Middle Management look after their own and that's it therefore sadly progression just does not happen.  Performance reviews are designed to talk you down for fear of creating more work in having to recruit new people therefore it's no surprise to see back office analysts at the age of 39!

As a field technician my time at Virgin went completely downhill as soon as liberty global took over. It's lost its fun values and a vast majority of techs have zero morale. Management is an absolute joke, no idea how to engage with their technicians, will never answer the phone to help and are constantly trying to build up evidence to pull you in for a disciplinary. There is no trust in techs and this is quite evident when they are watching your trackers all day. The workload is an absolute joke. Your whitespace no matter how small is always filled so there's absolutely no chance for you to recover if you have a job which takes longer than usual which happens most of the time seeing as you're only given 31 minutes to do a job where you're told you also have to try and generate 2 sales a month otherwise you can't get a good score in your 1 2 1. If you're feeling under the weather and don't feel like you can come jn to work you're bullied and intimidated to come in and complete your 16 jobs a day. For an HR consulting firm the internal experience as an employee is a joke: promotion processes are purposely opaque, the bonus you get each year does not at all seem to rely on your actual performance and peer reviews. Your future at the firm does depend a lot on your manager and their willingness to do their job properly or not – if not, do not count on HR to help you on anything as at Korn Ferry you are on your own. 
 
Management is outdated and every decision comes from the US even in markets for which local nuances would make a huge difference. CEO is out of touch with the employees, and his weekly emails repeating the same stories about his childhood and experiences are just one of the many clear signs of that. 
The rest of the leadership team is either completely disconnected from the field or is just left with no decision power and is trying to act like they know what they are doing when it is clear they do not. Local management has close to 0 power in the decision-making and is left watching their employees leave one after another. 
 
I cannot recall one of my colleagues being genuinely happy at this firm: people are either fearing to be laid off or just completely disengaged. Conversations around leaving the place are common. 
It seems like no one, including clients, is really believing in the strategy of the firm and/or fully understanding the position they are trying to build in the market. 

Ironically enough the firm seems to only care about numbers as you will constantly be asked to provide explanations around billable hours etc. BUT does not seem to act on any of it later: there is absolutely no anticipation of anything around hiring, using furlough, laying off people and decisions seem to be always so short-term it is actually scary. If you are going to spend time bothering people with numbers, DO USE THEM and try to look like there is a pilot on board. 

The COVID crisis has ended any kind of ethics that yet existed in the firm: the extensive use of furlough was just one example of it, massive layoffs being another. 
There is a culture of fear and if you stay too long their toxic environment will end up impacting your self-confidence and will make you stick around by fear of not finding another job/not being good enough: you will also end up being paid way below market as pay increases are close to non-existent. 

As a final note, the firm is developing their offer around D&I (or DE&I now) when there is absolutely no inclusion internally: the teams are NOT diverse, and the leadership team is mainly composed of white males in their late 50s. Even if they will try to showcase a different version, the truth is KF is still a very old boys’ club ruled by people with the same backgrounds, who share the same conservative ideas on how a workplace should be run. 
 
If you are a potential candidate, I would advise you stay away from this place. The negative reviews on Glassdoor DO matter and reflect the truth. This place will use you up and make you think that you are not good enough: there are other firms out there willing to invest in your development and career – go and work there.

I experienced workplace discrimination, harassment, and discrimination. Since this is a company that is suppose to excel at advising other companies, it was surprising. However, the Sr. Client Partners and Execs who bring in the work are "allowed" this behavior and a blind eye is turned since they bring in company revenue. This sense of entitlement, power, and lack of respect for others is what ultimately is the number one con. Additional cons are that there is little room for development beyond the SA role. Most partners are not vested in your career or development beyond that point.  You will also work 60 hours a week. There is high turnover  - in part because they don't give raises and a change in bonus structure is promised every year but doesn't happen.

There is no diversity amongst leads and management. Overall, this is a very racist company. Hard for minorities to move up the ladder. On an average, minorities receive lower income. Too much politics and finger pointing with every client. Disorganization and not enough raises and promotions within minorities. One thing I have noticed is that coworkers who work from home are extremely prejudice and set on their ways. We need those currently working from home to transition into the office environment which will teach them about diversity, acceptance and how to work with different personalities. Leads should not entertain or encourage coworkers who are apparently racists and bigots which is evident via email corresponding. There is no one to report these allegations to since HR and management are all friends, on the same team and play politics amongst each other.

They need to invest in skill training for the employees. Also have an internal HR whom you can reach out to. Have a career path mapped out for the delivery team. Also work out the compensation which matches the competition.

The business is reluctant to change and work actively to against it. Recommendations based on data are often easily dismissed. If you have found a team that collaborates, there is usually another one coming in playing short sighted politics. 
The senior management in the data team is unable to get on with a restructure that started over a year ago.
The tech stack is not fit for purpose (Windows 8, github blacklisted...) and the laptops are almost dying from the anti virus software that scans every read and write. 
There is no career progression internally, even though positions are open in the team. Salaries are not reviewed.
Ideas for a new use of data or to solve a business problem are not appreciated, even if you can show they work with a POC prototype. There is a data innovation lab, but you are not able to work with them because 'there is no business value'. 
A number of people have left, are under notice, or are planning to leave.

While this jobs started off great, we (I had started with a team of temps) quickly realised that we had not been properly trained to do our jobs correctly. We were part of the twilight shift working 7pm - midnight and this involved working alongside nightshift who soon made it clear what they thought of our training. 
While we had been hired as temps, we had been told by our manager that we would be kept on. He also agreed with me that when i returned to college he would reduce my hours so that i had more time for my studies. 
Unfortunately for us, he then got another job and left the branch. The new manager decided that he had no intention of keeping us and as a result we received no further training or assistance. His demands were unreasonable and unfair, expecting even experienced staff to manage workloads that they couldn't possibly do alone and then sending them for disciplinaries when they failed. 
I left before my temp contract was up because this manager refused to reduce my hours when I returned to college and I had to put my education and health first. 
I am still in contact with many of my old colleagues and staff moral is at an all time low. I am glad now that I escaped.

Good benefits and 401K including employer contribution.  However, never could understand how many people were bonused on the same sale especially the custom publishing ones. Sales staffs were often not given their annual sales goals until mid-year or later.  It was a big game with much number shuffling and smoke and mirrors.

Pearson was by far the best company I'd worked for, and were it not for COVID-19 changing life circumstances, I would still be there. I thoroughly enjoyed the opportunity to work on hard problems with smart colleagues all over the world. I don't know if it's just the UK-driven corporate culture and all UK companies are like this, but this experience is something I will treasure for the rest of professional career.

Pros:
-Pay and benefits were at or above market rate for IT skills in the area
-Global footprint, a huge, diverse workforce and an inclusive culture
-Focus on talent development and maximizing team capabilities
-Collegial, collaborative atmosphere and decent managers and management
-Management actively solicits new ideas and is open to engaging, and does not have an authoritarian/top-down approach to 'performance culture' that many US-headquartered companies do
Pearson is generally a great company with amazing potential in the global education space. Benefits are good.
Many people who work there are well intentioned, smart and care deeply about education. The company has the potential to revolutionize education.
Great people to work with. Flexible

refactoring and trying to do the right thing

Colleagues are bright, can do, interesting people who band together when the going gets tough, it's the people who keep you at Pearson.
The UK business is also very focussed on helping people achieve a good work life balance, so quite a few people work part time. It's  the most understanding employer I've come across when your child is sick, or you need time to help relatives etc. Though not sure what other geographies are like.
Good company to work till you retire

It's a face-paced environment with many extremely smart people who share a love of learning.   Outside of the staff positions, there's no such thing as a 35-hour work week and you have to accept and embrace that fact in order to succeed. More important, you have to care about education, learning, and helping others because that's the entire focus of the company. It's very competitive but it's also a meritocracy, so you can get promoted quickly if you deliver results. It's hard to identify a single culture because there are so many offices around the world. It's a particularly good fit for moms and dads with young children as the benefits and flex time are generous.
Great place to work!  Great people, great mission, and great environment!

The opportunity to work from home is available though I was not there long enough to earn that privilege. A caring and dedicated staff.

Higher ed division mismanaged and only got worse in recent years.  Company is trying to transition from print to digital but has no  real idea how to achieve this.  Uses terms like efficacy but no one really knows what that is supposed to mean much less explain it to the customer.  Often announced poorly timed, Ill thought or impractical initiatives and programs that never really got off the ground. They were often quietly scrapped and employees were strongly advised not to bring them up in even casual conversation.

Has been reorganizing for the past few years and no one really knows where this is headed (including many senior managers). Many, many employees are just keeping their heads down to not get noticed during the reorganization.
Expected to know new processes after being taught it once, even though you may not have to use the knowledge for 6 to 18 months.  Frustrating.

I can't speak for the whole company since it is global and it matters tremendously what business unit you are in. I used to love working here but my experience has gone downhill the past year with the restructuring. The bureaucracy has increased (including a travel policy with no airline preferences, you can't pay for assigned seats on cheap airlines so you scramble at the last minute, and taking late night or connecting flights to save $50). People in my area are leaving like rats from a sinking ship, and it feels like nobody in management cares. I assume things will stabilize over the next two years after the restructuring, but for now it's a tense and frustrating place to work.
The culture is terrible. Many people just putting their time in and defending turf. No corporate vision. Many layoffs. Can't deliver quality product - terrible technology.
